captions.text:
The BMW 5 Series is currently the reigning
CarBuyer best large executive car - but now

its been updated to fight off the revised
Mercedes E-Class. Though the updates are a

lot harder to spot than on the completely
facelifted Merc.

Round the back there are some redesigned lights
with LED strips and a new crease in the apron.

There are now indicator repeaters in the door
mirrors while at the front you get an new

grille surround, redesigned lower intake and
xenon headlamps now come as standard.

In fact that brings us on to equipment as
BMW has added more kit to the 5 Series. As

well as stuff like parking sensors, dual zone
climate and leather, you now get business

nav as standard and i-drive. In fact it has
a new controller which can read your finger

strokes making inputting destination to the
nav is even easier.

Other changes to the car's cabin are restricted
to some shiny trim round the instruments -- I'll

leave you to try and spot exactly where it
is.... and slightly bigger cupholders and

cubby holes which do help boost practicality
somewhat.

In terms of how well screwed together this
car is - the pre-facelifted 5 Series ranked

3rd for build quality in the 2013 driver Power
owner satisfaction Survey and this one should

be no different. If you want you can rate
your car now at driverpower.co.uk by clicking
here.

One of the great things about the 5 Series
has always been the way it drives and there

is no change there. It still offers a great
blend of fun rear-drive handling, sharp steering,

excellent comfort and a quite drive at motorway
speeds.

You can get the 5 series with a wide range
of excellent engines but most people will

be more than satisfied with the 2.0-litre
diesel in this 520d car. There is no longer

an efficient dynamics model like before -- the
520d economical is as economical as it gets

being capable of up to 63mpg and less than
120g/km CO2.

With 181bhp it's no slouch either as 0-62mph
takes a little over 8 seconds while in gear
shove is even more impressive.

If there is a problem with the engine it's
that it's a bit rattly at low speeds. Also

it's not quite as efficient in M Sport model
on account of that cars slightly different
front bumper and larger wheels.

M Sport also features this multifunction steering
wheel and firmer suspension which does makes

ride harder, though if you buy this car you
really should spend an extra £1K for the

adjustable suspension as without it the 5
series doesn't drive as well as it can.

In fact BMW doesn't have a normally sprung
car on its press fleet. I'm surprised they

sent us one with a manual gearbox too. The
six speed manual isn't exactly the slickest

and the pedals are offset whereas the 8 speed
auto is among the best in the business -- but

yeah, once again it's gonna cost you extra
-- only this time £1,700 extra. BMW and their
must-have options.... Drives you mad...

So too will the fact you even have to pay
extra for fold down rear seats. They are standard

on an Audi A6 which incidentally has a slightly
bigger boot, though to be fair, not by much.

And then there is the space in the back. It's
really good with sufficient head and legroom,

but it still doesn't feel quite as comfy as
a Mercedes E-Class back here. The transmission

tunnel does reduce the usefulness of the middle
seat though that's a problem on all these
executive cars anyway.

And out of all the Executive cars, while it
may not be perfect the BMW 5 Series is still

the boss - though its rivals do run it very
close. In fact you can see a review of the

new Mercedes E-Class here and one of the Audi
A6 here. And of course you can click on our
logo to subscribe to our channel.
